themes: Loss of authentic arts focus in funding programs
Lack of genuine equity in program design
Excessive academic/elitist barriers in application process
Negative staff experiences (except for one individual)
key_phrases: The actual arts component must be restored
the names are silly and illustrate that the people creating them were not serious about equity
Grant programs should be named according to who and what they are for
the applicant is forced to do the extra work of researching
the questions betrayed an elitist, academic lens
I shouldn't need a graduate degree in social theory to fill out an arts grant
the staff is terrible, except for Anne-Marie
barriers_identified: Confusing or unclear program names requiring extra research
Elitist, academic language in application questions
Unwelcoming or unsupportive staff (with one exception)
solutions_proposed: Rename grant programs to clearly state who and what they are for (e.g., 'Visual Arts Support for Women of Color')
Simplify application questions to remove academic/elitist barriers
